publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: By a LADY
ALL ye POETS of the Age
Lash this Fool, now on the Stage
Whose base Verses, vilely flow
Smoothly Spightful, row by row.
Tho' his Lesson he begins
Like a Boy in Leading Strings,
Little Wit, and Tittle Tattle
Serves for Children's prittle prattleNamby Pamby is the strain
Where he shows his Nonsence vain,
Mocking th' Wise he is so Jolly
More and more to show his Folly,
Silly Scoggin, discontented,
'Cause his Purpose was prevented.
With proud Impudence we see
Him despising Dignity.
Making th' End of his fool story
A screen to shade our Phil────ps Glory
Phil────p's Poems wise and Witty
While his being not so's foul and S────ty.
Silly Rymer with his Babble
To please none fit but foolish Rabble.
He afraid to loose the PYE:
Puts his Finger in his EYE
Baby crying for a Plum!
Putting in, in vain his Thumb.
Then he shows great Vexation,
'Cause he cant Imploy the Nation,
And like a simpleton goes sneering
Fancies Nonsense worth our hearing,
Singing them of Lickspit Lyar
Makes his Verses fit for Fire
Trumping all his Stuff together
Like an Empty Rattle Bladder.
He has found some Baby's Play
And therefore Idly spends the DaySimple Sawny sure tis he
Whose fit to See saw on a Tree.
Or call Children out together
With his proclaiming Pleasant Weather.
Being turn'd Idle Fool.
He's been whip'd out, from his School.
Yet with his noise of Rittle Rattle,
He continues Prittle Prattle.And 'cause our Phil────ps does exceed him,
He'd not have the World to heed him.
Branding him with Jacky Horner
He shews himself a Babbling Scorner
Baby-Clouts befit the Bumpking
And a Cock-Horse, fits his hunting.
He then frets, alas! poor HE,
Must sit down Scorn'd in low degree,
Yet he thinks he's brave and Witty,
And his Senseless POEMS pritty,
Spightful Scoggin what a Place.
Could he Expect from's Gracy Grace
Whom he does with Impudence
Brand, as wanting Commonsense.Namby Pamby's yet his Prate
Solid Sense the fool does hate.
Choosing Folly to his guide
He makes of Excrements his Pride.
For which, O! all In────nal Powers
Watch him well in Dying hours
Blast his Joy and break his heart,
For playing now this odious part.
A Scorning Scriblers Fate o're take him.
A Garret high! and heart of't Aking
Le'st his Farthing Goods should bring him,
To Tripple Tyburn and there Swing him.
Not this alone, may all his Pens,
When'ere he writes Split from the Ends.
And best Ink be turn'd to Water,
When most h' intends to move our Lafter:
